item.title: Russia Is Reportedly Making Two Video Game Consoles
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/russia-is-reportedly-making-two-video-game-consoles/1100-6528612/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Russia is looking to enter the video game console space by creating its own systems, and the country is reportedly planning on making two different kinds as it continues to feel the economic impact of its illegal invasion of Ukraine.

According to TechSpot, one of them is reportedly a traditional console using the Elbrus processor, which is developed by the Moscow Center of SPARC Technologies. This processor is mainly used for applications such as critical infrastructure and defense. It's also reportedly going to use a domestic OS--either Aurora or Alt Linux.

In a statement on Telegram, deputy chairman of the State Duma Committee on information policy Anton Gorelkin confirmed that Elbrus processors aren't as powerful as the ones used in PS5 or Xbox, so Russia will have to take a unique approach to its consoles.

He also said that it won't be designed to play ports of older games, but serve as a platform to encourage domestic video game development.

The second console is reportedly a cloud-based one built by the Russian telecommunications firm MTS and will cost $45. It will reportedly utilize MTS' Fog Play--its cloud-based gaming platform that lets owners of high-end PCs to charge an hourly price to those with less powerful machines.

As Russia has been sanctioned due to its invasion of Ukraine, the government is looking to promote more domestic technology. Last year, Russian President Vladimir Putin initiated the government to create its own video game consoles, and Microsoft has said that Russia has been infiltrating the gaming community.

George Yang on Google+

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Half-Life Actor Stirs Up Half-Life 3 Rumors With Cryptic New Year's Message
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/half-life-actor-stirs-up-half-life-3-rumors-with-cryptic-new-years-message/1100-6528613/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

For the last two decades, players have looked for any sign that Valve is moving forward with Half-Life 3. The 20th anniversary of Half-Life 2 came and went without any announcement about the long-awaited sequel. Now, actor Mike Shapiro, who voices the enigmatic G-Man in the Half-Life games, has shared a cryptic New Year's message on X that has some fans speculating that Half-Life 3 could finally arrive this year.

In the brief recording, Shapiro revisits his unsettling G-Man voice as he says, "May the next quarter century deliver as many unexpected surprises, as did the millennium's first." He then cryptically notes that time is fluid like music, before adding that he'll "see you in the new year."

This message follows a previous report by Valve leaker Gabe Follower, who claims that Half-Life 3 recently entered play testing for "family and friends of Valve developers." If so, that would be a remarkable cone of silence from the trusted few, since there haven't been many other reports that suggest a new game is closer than expected.

Fans of the series have been eagerly hoping for some kind of resolution to the cliffhanger ending of the 2007 expansion Half-Life 2 Episode 2, which left the heroes in dire straights. There were originally plans for Half-Life 2: Episode 3, which would have been set in the Arctic. According to the Half-Life 2 documentary released by Valve last year, Episode 3 was in development for six months before it was abandoned. Instead, the team went to work on Left 4 Dead. Since then, the only new title in the franchise was the VR game Half-Life: Alyx in 2020.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Hi-Fi Rush Studio Officially Reborn At PUBG Company
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/hi-fi-rush-studio-officially-reborn-at-pubg-company/1100-6528610/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Tango Gameworks is dead; long live Tango Gameworks Inc. That's the new "reborn" name of the Hi-Fi Rush studio, which is now officially a part of PUBG publisher Krafton Inc. Tango began last year under the Xbox Game Studios umbrella before a tumultuous few months saw the developer almost shuttered permanently before Krafton stepped in.

On X, Tango announced the studio's "new start" earlier this week and said it's "excited to continue crafting games that bring joy to players around the world." This is the first post from the official Tango account since May 7, 2024, when the developer stated that it would "close." That message was a result of Tango being one of four studios that Microsoft shut down at the time, which also included Redfall's Arkane Austin.

However, in August, Tango was saved by Krafton, with Hi-Fi Rush rights being acquired as well. The studio was started in 2010 and known for the survival-horror series The Evil Within, which will apparently stay with Microsoft. Hi-Fi Rush 2 was being worked on before Microsoft closed down Tango, though the sequel isn't officially on the way. Krafton realizes Hi-Fi Rush 2 might not make any money, and that's okay for the company--if Tango decides to move forward with that project.

Krafton CEO Changhan Kim stated last year that giving Tango the support to continue being creative and developing new experiences was key. For more, check out GameSpot's Hi-Fi Rush review. The rhythm-action game was a surprise release in early 2023.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Kojima Says OD And Physint Were Impacted By Strike
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/kojima-says-od-and-physint-were-impacted-by-strike/1100-6528609/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Game designer Hideo Kojima provided an update on his in-development games, including Death Stranding 2: On the Beach, OD, and Physint. Starting with the latter two, both were impacted by the SAG-AFTRA strike for video game actors, which began in July 2024 and remains ongoing.

For OD, which is in the works alongside Microsoft and Xbox, Kojima said his teams "developed the game" and did scanning efforts for environments and the actors themselves. Scanning and filming for OD was suspended due to the strike, however. For Physint, which is being published by Sony, Kojima said casting was suspended due to the strike. "We hope to resume [in 2025]," Kojima said.

As for Death Stranding 2, Kojima said, "We started to play and build up the game." He added that his teams conducted music production and recording, along with ADR for the actors.

Games that went into development prior to September 2023 are understood to be exempt from the strike, along ongoing with live-service games. This likely explains why OD and Physint were impacted but Death Stranding 2 was not.

OD will feature the actors Sophia Lillis, Hunter Schafer, and Udo Kier, with Oscar-winning director Jordan Peele contributing to the script. The cast for Physint, meanwhile, is unknown at this point. Death Stranding 2, meanwhile, features Norman Reedus, Lea Seydoux, Troy Baker, Elle Fanning, and other celebrities.

The strike began July 26, at 12:01 AM. It's the first time SAG-AFTRA video game actors have gone on strike since 2016, when the work stoppage lasted for about one year.

SAG-AFTRA and game publishers like Warner Bros., Activision, Disney, and others, negotiated for about two years prior to the strike being called. The key sticking point appears to be regulation of generative AI technology.

Beyond games, Kojima said preparations and planning are underway for the Death Stranding movie and "other adaptations" of Kojima's games. When Physint was announced, Kojima also confirmed a partnership with Sony's Columbia Pictures, so it seems there could be a Physint film in the works as well.

Kojima attended The Game Awards in December 2024, but had no announcements to share.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: CoD: Black Ops 6 Might Include A Paid Event Pass For Squid Game Collab
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/cod-black-ops-6-might-include-a-paid-event-pass-for-squid-game-collab/1100-6528608/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

A new update is scheduled for Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 and Warzone on December 3, which includes the recently announced Squid Game crossover event. In addition to new operator bundles, the event also includes other Squid Game-themed rewards, but some of the items appear to be locked behind an additional paywall.

As previously reported by CharlieIntel, Black Ops 6's in-game message board teased more details about the upcoming Squid Game event. This includes special limited-time modes themed around the hit Netflix show as well as an event pass for with a "premium track" that requires an additional purchase. This premium pass is said to include the Front Man operator skin and other cosmetic items.

In the past, Call of Duty has included other major IP collaborations with event rewards themed around Fallout, The Walking Dead, Dune, Warhammer, and more. Outside of the shop bundles, all of the event rewards could be earned for free by completing challenges or simply earning XP. This upcoming Squid Game event has the potential to be the first to lock some of the rewards behind an additional cost.

Activision hasn't revealed the full details of the Squid Game event, so we don't know how much it costs, and it's possible the details could change between now and the launch date. Currently, Black Ops 6 is a $70 game with the options for either a $10 standard battle pass or $30 extra-premium BlackCell pass for each season. It's also available via several Game Pass plans across Xbox and PC.

The Call of Duty and Squid Game crossover trailer can be seen above, which shows off several operator skins themed around the show. Season 1 of Call of Duty is currently winding down, and Season 2 should arrive near the end of January.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Black Myth: Wukong Developer Says Xbox Port Delay Is Due To The Series S
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/black-myth-wukong-developer-says-xbox-port-delay-is-due-to-the-series-s/1100-6528607/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The developer of Black Myth: Wukong has said that the reason for the delay of its Xbox port is due to the Series S due to the Series S's memory being a bottleneck.

Over on Weibo, a Chinese social media app, GameScience CEO Feng Ji said that the Xbox Series S's 10GB of shared memory is a problem and has caused optimization issues. Last year, Microsoft stated that the game's delay was not due to Xbox hardware limitations, but the Series S has run into this problem before.

Black Myth: Wukong GameSpot Review

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Baldur's Gate 3 was the biggest example of this, as it was released late for Xbox in 2023 as a result of technical issues related to the Series S version. Black Myth: Wukong was also reportedly a console exclusive for PlayStation 5, although neither Game Science nor Sony ever confirmed it.

Black Myth Wukong was a nominee for the coveted Game of the Year award at The Game Awards 2024. While it didn't win that particular category, it did win Best Action Game. It also managed to snag its own Game of the Year win at The Steam Awards 2024.

So far, Black Myth: Wukong has sold 18 million copies and an expansion is on the way. It also recently received a huge update last month adding new equipment and quality-of-life features. The game is available on PC and PS5, but it's still unclear when the Xbox version will come out.

George Yang on Google+

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Helldivers 2 Studio Working On Next Game, Reveals Concepts That Never Materialized
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/helldivers-2-studio-working-on-next-game-reveals-concepts-that-never-materialized/1100-6528606/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Helldivers 2 was one of 2024's biggest games, and while support remains ongoing, many are wondering what developer Arrowhead Studios might make next. We still don't know, but COO Johan Pilestedt has now confirmed he has an idea for what the team may make next.

Posting on social media, Pilestedt said, "What are your expectations and desires for what the next Arrowhead game will be? I am working on the high concept..."

The executive then invited people to share their "speculation" as to what Arrowhead could build next. One person said they'd like to see Arrowhead make a Star Fox-style game where players zip around on aircraft during on-rails missions before a level becomes open-world during a boss fight. Pilestedt said this matches up with the concept for a game Arrowhead wanted to make, "Eagles of Democracy." He even shared some images of this title--check them out below.

Someone else said they want to see Arrowhead develop a remake of the 1990 retro twin-stick shooter Smash TV. Pilestedt said his team actually created a high concept for this, saying it was aiming to be a top-down re-imagining of the classic arcade game.

The executive didn't elaborate as to why these two concepts never materialized. However, it's not uncommon in the creative process for ideas to be conceived and then never amount to anything.

While fans wait to see what Arrowhead might make next, there is still lots more planned for Helldivers 2 as part of its live-service programming. Its latest DLC, a crossover with Killzone, launched in December and didn't go over perfectly with fans due its pricing and other issues. Arrowhead made changes and apologized to fans over this.

As of November 2024, Helldivers 2 is the No. 3 best-selling game of 2024, trailing only Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 and College Football 25.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: GTA 6 Could Make $3 Billion In First Year Alone
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/gta-5-could-make-3-billion-in-first-year-alone/1100-6528605/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

According to a research company, Grand Theft Auto VI could bring in more than $3 billion in total revenues during the first 12 months after launch. A report from Financial Times cites data from DFC Intelligence that says GTA 6 could bring in $3.2 billion in its first year and that the game is likely to surpass $1 billion in preorder revenue alone.

The report didn't mention how DFC might have arrived at these estimates or if they also included revenue from microtransactions and sales of any potential GTA VI premium editions. GameSpot has contacted DFC in an attempt to get more details.

GTA 6 earning a mountain of money would be one of the least-surprising pieces of news in video game history. After all, it's the sequel to one of the world's most popular video games, and hype for the open-world title is already massive and continues to grow.

For comparison, GTA 5 earned $1 billion in revenue after just 72 hours on sale back in September 2013. This did not include any GTA Online revenue, either, as GTA Online did not release until October 2013.

Take-Two boss Strauss Zelnick told FT that he would "never claim victory before it occurs." However, Zelnick said he feels confident that Rockstar Games will release "something absolutely phenomenal."

GTA 6 has been in development for many years already, though it wasn't until February 2022 that Rockstar Games officially acknowledged the game's existence. The FT report cited estimates for the game's development costs (it didn't mention marketing costs) as being between the "high hundreds of millions" to more than $2 billion, including costs for the game's expected post-launch updates.

GTA 6 has enormous shoes to fill, as GTA 5 has sold more than 205 million copies, making it the No. 3 best-selling game ever, only behind Minecraft and Tetris.

GTA 6 is officially set for launch in Fall 2025, a window that Take-Two has committed to on multiple occasions. Some believe the game may slip to 2026, in part because every Rockstar game from the past decade has been delayed beyond its original publicly announced date. Others believe the game might have already been delayed internally, based on reports that GTA 6 has missed multiple internal deadlines.

What we do know is that Rockstar went an entire year without uttering a peep about GTA 6. The game's first trailer debuted in December 2023. Many expected Rockstar to release the next trailer at some point in 2024, but that did not happen, despite the so-called evidence that fans believe they discovered. Zelnick recently said he understands fans are growing impatient, but Rockstar refuses to release the game until it's ready.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
